I’m an Anglican because I believe it to be the only Reformational Church (besides some Lutherans) to have ordained clergy capable of administering the sacraments. Some may call this harsh, but I fear that historical record is quite harsh on this issue—Bishops are necessary.
It introduced a discontinuity not seen before and has now made it very difficult to identify the Church—at least properly speaking. It also hugely interferes with ecumenical dialog.

The clearest instance of innovation during the time of the reformation was an abandonment of the episcopacy. There was no reason to change this; historically and scripturally. I truly believe that it was one of the most devastating parts of the reformation.

@_matthewpearson @john_law_3 @RonOffringa ‘Twas a good social experiment. My concern is maintaining that man’s nature, though corrupted, is still good. That’s something I see in Aquinas that I think is important to avoid a sort of Gnosticism.

@_matthewpearson @RonOffringa It seems that Aquinas maintained the inherent goodness of man’s nature, despite its corruption through original sin. I want to be careful not to delve into a gnostic line of thinking about human nature, while also avoiding glorifying that which is truly fallen apart from grace.

@_matthewpearson @RonOffringa I’m not sure I’d agree that man is always inclined towards a degenerate will. I agree that all things apart from faith is sin, but not all sin is evil in character—morally good actions done apart from faith are sin, but not evil on a moral level.

@RonOffringa It mainly has to do with some the reformed thought surrounding the nature of man. The contrast would be between say Aquinas and someone like Van Til. Though they would both admit to depravity, what they mean is quite different.
